awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Macroevolution of a group of plant secondary defense compounds (pyrrolizidine alkaloids) in the dogbane and milkweed flowering plant family (Apocynaceae)
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants are known to synthesize about 200,000 distinct secondary metabolites, chemical compounds that are not essential for their cellular metabolism. These plant secondary chemicals are important sources of medicines (e.g. aspirin), pesticides (e.g. pyrethrin), industrial compounds (e.g. latex), flavors (e.g. mint), and poisons (e.g. strychnine). To plants, these chemicals are essential defenses against herbivores, particularly insects. The efficacy of these defenses is not static over time, however, as herbivores adapt to their host plants defenses, evolving mechanisms to detoxify them or even co-opt them for their own defense against their predators. Thus a chemical that was once a valuable defense may become a liability, and its production lost. This project will investigate the evolution of a group of plant defense secondary compounds (pyrrolizidine alkaloids) in the dogbane and milkweed family (Apocynaceae). Plant secondary compounds in the Apocynaceae are diverse, with many having medicinal properties. Pyrrolizidine alkaloids in members of the Apocynaceae are highly toxic to non-adapted herbivores, but have little effect on specialist insects that store them within their tissues for defense against predators. Researchers will sample broadly across the Apocynaceae and reconstruct evolutionary relationships within the family using DNA sequence data. The resulting evolutionary tree will then be used as a framework to reconstruct the evolution of pyrrolizidine alkaloids within the group and better understand the relationship between these chemicals, the plants that produce them, and their herbivores. Undergraduate students will be trained in diverse molecular, evolutionary and biochemistry methods. Results from this project will also be integrated into undergraduate classes at three institutions, including two primarily undergraduate institutions. The research will provide new insights into evolutionary relationships within the medically important Apocynaceae plant family that can be used as a framework for broader questions within the family. An exhibit at the Academy of Natural Sciences in Philadelphia will broadly disseminate results from this research, and information on the broader topics of plant and insect defense, chemistry, and co-evolution, to the public. 

The overarching hypothesis to be tested in this research project proposes that the diversity of pyrrolizidine alkaloids will be lower in plant lineages that are highly exploited by insects immune to the effects of these compounds. To test this hypothesis researchers will use a combination of targeted enrichment and genome skimming (Hyb-Seq) to sequence ca. 850 low-copy nuclear loci, whole chloroplast genomes, and nuclear ribosomal genes, from 2 species of each of the 287 genera of the APSA clade (the lineage within Apocynaceae that includes most known milkweed butterfly host plants) to generate the required well-resolved and supported phylogeny and chronogram of the family. Researchers will then conduct a systematic survey of pyrrolizidine alkaloids occurrence in leaves across the APSA clade and reconstruct the evolution of both the pyrrolizidine alkaloids phenotype and of the underlying biosynthetic pathway, as well as expression and functional analyses in a subset of species. The origin of pyrrolizidine alkaloid biosynthesis in Apocynaceae will then be compared to the age of pyrrolizidine alkaloid co-option by Danainae, and test if the loss of pyrrolizidine alkaloids is correlated with host plant status.

por.por_cntn:
We reconstructed the evolutionary relationships of plants in the milkweed and dogbane family (Apocynaceae) and used this framework to investigate the evolution of pyrrolizidine alkaloids (PAs), an important class of plant defensive chemicals. We hypothesized that there has been a de-escalation of this defense over time as insect herbivores adapted to PAs.

To this end, we developed probes for targeted sequencing of 835 nuclear genes in Apocynaceae and demonstrated their utility for inferring evolutionary relationships at multiple scales, including population-level studies, which will be useful for other researchers. Using data from these nuclear genes, a universal set of nuclear genes (Angiosperms-353), and whole chloroplast genomes for hundreds of milkweed and dogbane species, we resolved the relationships of the major lineages of Apocynaceae. A close relationship between tribes Apocyneae and Echiteae, Mesechiteae, and Odontadenieae was strongly supported for the first time. Furthermore, we clarified the evolutionary position of one lineage, Periplocoideae, which had remained unplaced despite numerous previous attempts by us and other research groups over the last twenty years. This new information increases our understanding of the evolution of key traits including pollen aggregation. We identified which analytical choices contributed to the placement by teasing apart the relative contributions of increasing the number of species sampled, increasing the number of genes sampled, and other characteristics of the analysis such as the information contributed by each gene.

We used chloroplast genome data to investigate the history and evolution of other important morphological traits in Apocynaceae. From a woody, self-supporting ancestor, other growth forms (e.g., herbaceous, climbing, succulent) evolved multiple times, and there were frequent shifts back and forth between these growth forms over evolutionary time. The ancestral fruit type was likely a berry followed by the evolution of multiple other fruit types, especially dry fruits, as the group diversified into new habitat types, moving from tropical forests into more open habitats where other modes of dispersal of seeds, such as via wind, were possible.

 In addition to the resolution of evolutionary relationships, more information on the distribution of PAs among Apocynaceae species was required to test our hypothesis. In collaboration with Dr. Kevin Minbiole, new methods for detecting PAs in small amounts of dried plant tissue, including museum specimens, were developed, and then used to assess species of Apocynaceae for PA production. More than 200 species representing over 80% of the major Apocynaceae lineages were surveyed. Six genera that were not previously known to produce PAs were identified, and we concluded that PAs are a chemical trait of the tribe Echiteae.

 In our initial analyses, we inferred a single origin of PAs in Apocynaceae followed by multiple losses because a single gene duplication gave rise to homospermidine synthase (HSS), an essential gene of PA biosynthesis, in all PA-producing Apocynaceae species. In contrast, our final analyses, with greatly expanded sampling and additional analyses of HSS function and selection, showed that the evolution of the PA biosynthetic pathway was potentially more complex. Some of our new results continued to support the initial finding of a single origin of HSS and PAs, followed by multiple losses, while other analyses support multiple independent recruitments of HSS into PA biosynthesis. While we made much progress in understanding the evolution of PAs, additional data and analyses will be required to complete the picture of PA evolution in Apocynaceae.

We trained and mentored students who will become the next generation of scientists through this project. One Ph.D. student and 15 undergraduate researchers enrolled at Hobart and William Smith Colleges (New York) and Drexel University (Pennsylvania) were part of the research team. In addition to research, some students engaged in science communication and education by designing crafts and games related to their research that they shared with elementary school students in the Geneva City School District (New York). We conducted professional outreach in the form of workshops at national scientific conferences where attendees, made up of undergraduate and graduate students, postdocs, government scientists, and academic faculty gained background knowledge and practical data analysis skills for incorporating the latest advances in DNA sequencing technology into their plant science research. We produced a video communicating our research questions and results for the general public that is shown at the Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University and available to the public online.
